QCA API¶

Software support for the documentation of Applications for Quantum Computers

Utils¶

qca.utils.get_T_depth(cpt_circuit: AbstractCircuit) → int¶

For some clifford + T circuit, grab the total T depth

Parameters:

cpt_circuit (cirq.AbstractCirquit) – A clifford + T circuit

Returns:

The T depth of the circuit

Return type:

int

qca.utils.count_gates(cpt_circuit: AbstractCircuit) → int¶

For some clifford + T circuit, iterate through it and sum up the number of gates

Parameters:

cpt_circuit (cirq.AbstractCircuit) – A clifford + T circuit

Returns:

The number of gates in the clifford + T circuit

Return type:

int

qca.utils.estimate_gsee(circuit: Circuit, outdir: str, circuit_name: str = 'gse_circuit', write_circuits: bool = False) → None¶

Perform ground state energy estimation (gsee) on some circuit and write out the results if desired

Parameters:

  • circuit (cirq.Circuit) – The circuit to perform gsee on

  • outdir (str) – The directory to save the results to

  • circuit_name (str) – The name of the circuit, defaults to gse_circuit

  • write_circuits (bool) – Flag to denote whether or not to save the results to disk

Returns:

None

qca.utils.extract_number(string: str) → int | None¶

For some string, return a number from it if it exists

Parameters:

string (str type) – the string to evaluate

Returns:

Either the number found or None

Return type:

Union[int, None]

qca.utils.plot_histogram(cpt_circuit: AbstractCircuit, histogram_title: str, figdir: str, widthdir: str, lowest_ind: int = 0, **kwargs) → None¶

For some clifford + T circuit, plot its histogram

Parameters:

  • cpt_circuit (cirq.AbstractCircuit) – A clifford + T circuit

  • histogram_title (str) – The title to give your histogram

  • widthdir (str) – The T width

  • lowest_ind (int) – Lowest index to plot

  • kwargs – Additional arguments for plotting the histogram

Returns:

None

qca.utils.get_T_depth_wire(cpt_circuit: AbstractCircuit) → int¶

Grab the maximum number of T-gates on a wire. This may be more optimistic than number of layers with T-gates. Perhaps good to treat as lower bound for an implementation

Parameters:

cpt_circuit (cirq.AbstractCircuit) – A clifford + T circuit

Returns:

The maximum T depth on a wire

Return type:

int

qca.utils.plot_T_step_histogram(cpt_circuit: AbstractCircuit, kwargs, lowest_ind: int = 0) → hist¶

For some clifford + T circuit, grab its corresponding histogram

Parameters:

  • cpt_circuit (cirq.AbstractCircuit) – A clifford + T circuit

  • kwargs – Additional arguments for plotting the histogram

  • lowest_ind (int) – Lowest index to plot

Returns:

The corresponding histogram

Return type:

plt.hist

Hamiltonian Utils¶

qca.hamiltonian_utils.flatten_nx_graph(graph: Graph) → Graph¶

Given some graph, flatten it

Parameters:

graph (networkx.Graph) – The graph to be flattened

Returns:

The flattened graph

Return type:

networkx.Graph

qca.hamiltonian_utils.nx_triangle_lattice(lattice_size: int) → Graph¶

Given some lattice size, generate a triangle Hamiltonian graph

Parameters:

lattice_size (int) – Lattice size to use to construct the Hamiltonian graph

Returns:

The generated Hamiltonian using triangle lattices

Return type:

networkx.Graph

qca.hamiltonian_utils.assign_hexagon_labels(graph: Graph, x: str = 'X', y: str = 'Y', z: str = 'Z') → None¶

Given some Hamiltonian expressed as a graph, assign its labels. We take as input x, y, and z labels that are default to ‘X’, ‘Y’, and ‘Z’ respectively.

Parameters:

  • graph (networkx.Graph) – The Hamiltonian to be labeled

  • x (str) – X label, defaults to ‘X’

  • y (str) – Y label, defaults to ‘Y’

  • z (str) – Z label, defaults to ‘Z’

Returns:

None

qca.hamiltonian_utils.generate_two_orbital_nx(Lx: int, Ly: int) → Graph¶

Given some lattice size in both the x and y dimension, generate a two orbital Hamiltonian

Parameters:

  • Lx (int) – Lattice size in the x dimension

  • Ly (int) – Lattice size in the y dimension

Returns:

The generated two orbital Hamiltonian graph

Return type:

networkx.Graph

qca.hamiltonian_utils.nx_transverse_ising_terms(graph: Graph, p: float, magnitude=0.1) → list[tuple[str, float]]¶

Given a networkx graph, construct a Hamiltonian with random weights which can be processed by pyLIQTR in terms of its transverse ising terms

Parameters:

  • graph (networkx.Graph) – The graph to construct the Hamiltonian from

  • p (float) – transverse weight probability

  • magnitude (float) – magnitude to assign weight to if some random value is larger than the longitudinal weight probability

Returns:

A list of tuples containing the Hamiltonian string and its weights

Return type:

list[tuple[str, float]]

qca.hamiltonian_utils.generate_square_hamiltonian(lattice_size: int, dim: int, longitudinal_weight_prob: float = 0.5, transverse_weight_prob: float = 1) → tuple[list[tuple[str, float]], list[tuple[str, float]]]¶

Given some lattice size, longitudinal weight probability, and transverse weight probability, generate a flattened square Hamiltonian.

Parameters:

  • lattice_size (int) – The lattice size to use to construct the Hamiltonian

  • longitudinal_weight_prob (float) – probability for a weight in the longitudinal field

  • transverse_weight_prob (float) – probability for a weight in the transverse field

Returns:

A tuple containing the terms to the transverse portion of the Hamiltonian and the longitudinal portion of the Hamiltonian

Return type:

tuple[list[tuple[str, float]], list[tuple[str, float]]]

qca.hamiltonian_utils.nx_longitudinal_ising_terms(graph: Graph, p: float, magnitude: float = 1) → list[tuple[str, float]]¶

Given a networkx graph, construct a Hamiltonian with random weights which can be processed by pyLIQTR in terms of its longitudinal ising terms

Parameters:

  • graph (networkx.Graph) – The graph to construct the Hamiltonian from

  • p (float) – longitudinal weight probability

  • magnitude (float) – magnitude to assign weight to if some random value is larger than the longitudinal weight probability

Returns:

A list of tuples containing the Hamiltonian string and its weights

Return type:

list[tuple[str, float]]

qca.hamiltonian_utils.generate_triangle_hamiltonian(lattice_size: int, longitudinal_weight_prob: float = 0.5, transverse_weight_prob: float = 1) → tuple[list[tuple[str, float]], list[tuple[str, float]]]¶

Given some lattice size, longitudinal weight probability, and transverse weight probability, generate a flattened triangle Hamiltonian.

Parameters:

  • lattice_size (int) – The lattice size to use to construct the Hamiltonian

  • longitudinal_weight_prob (float) – probability for a weight in the longitudinal field

  • transverse_weight_prob (float) – probability for a weight in the transverse field

Returns:

A tuple containing the terms to the transverse portion of the Hamiltonian and the longitudinal portion of the Hamiltonian

Return type:

tuple[list[tuple[str, float]], list[tuple[str, float]]]

qca.hamiltonian_utils.nx_to_two_orbital_hamiltonian(graph: Graph, t1: float, t2: float, t3: float, t4: float, mu: float) → FermionOperator¶

Given somme Hamiltonian graph and several weights, perform a conversion from a two orbital Hamiltonian graph to a two orbital FermionOperator.

Parameters:

  • graph (networkx.Graph) – The Hamiltonian graph to be converted

  • t1 (float) – t1 weight

Pram mu:

Number operator

Returns:

The converted FermionOperator

Return type:

FermionOperator

Given some Hamiltonian graph which has some size, iterate through it and assign its labels.

Parameters:

  • g (networkx.Graph) – The Hamiltonian graph to be labeled

  • lattice_size (int) – The lattice size

Returns:

None

qca.hamiltonian_utils.pyliqtr_hamiltonian_to_openfermion_qubit_operator(H: Hamiltonian) → QubitOperator¶

Given some pyLIQTR Hamiltonian type, convert it to a openfermion Qubit Operator

Parameters:

H (Hamiltonian) – The Hamiltonian to be converted

Returns:

The converted QubitOperator

QubitOperator
